head.title: Song II.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 214-216.

lg.l: Upon a bank where linnets sung,
Where rows of nodding lilies sprung,
And streams fell trickling down,
Young Colin22 Shepherd-poet, Cf. Clement Marot’s Complainte de Madame Loysc (1531); Edmund Spenser’s Shepheardes Calendar (1579); and John Gay’s The Shepherd’s Week (1714). sat beneath the shade,
While round his sportive lambkins stray’d,
As on his rural pipe he play’d,

And sung of Molly Brown.33 Perhaps a misprint for "Molly Bawn," a traditional Irish ballad ciculated by Jamieson under the name of "Lord Kenneth and Fair Ellinour" in 1799 and later published in Jamieson, Popular Ballads, vol. 1, (1806), 194.
Away, he cry’d, ye wanton maids,
Who sport beneath the woodland shades,
Or triumph o’er the town;
Retire, for ah! I know full well,
With envy ev’ry breast would swell,
To hear me half the beauties tell
Of charming Molly Brown.
When o’er the dewy mead she strays,
The wond’ring shepherds round her gaze,
And all enamour’d own,
That never, never yet was seen
A nymph that trode the flow’ry green,
Of such a matchless shape and mien,
As charming Molly Brown.
Let fops, in many a labour’d line,
The blooming rose and lily twine
Some damsel’s head to crown;
Yet those, with all their labour’d art,
Can ne’er such rapt’rous strains impart,
As flow spontaneous from the heart,
Inspir’d by Molly Brown.
Her charms the coldest heart can fire,
They wake the soul to soft desire,
And joy before unknown;
For her would hermits quit their cell,
And bid their solitude farewell,
And on the plains delighted dwell,
To gaze on Molly Brown.
O would the gen’rous pow’rs above
Grant me my charming Molly’s love,
I’d other joys disown;
Let others treasure gold in store,
And shining orient gems adore,
Far happier I, possess’d of more,
In charming Molly Brown.
